units.LF: Linear Feet - length measurement for pipe, curb, etc.
units.CY: Cubic Yard - volume measurement for concrete, excavation, fill
units.SY: Square Yard - area measurement for paving, erosion blanket
units.SF: Square Feet - area measurement for forming, surfaces
units.TON: Ton (2000 lbs) - weight measurement for aggregate, asphalt
units.EA: Each - count for fittings, structures, valves
units.LS: Lump Sum - flat price for a scope of work
units.GAL: Gallon - volume for liquids like tack coat
units.HR: Hour - time measurement for labor and equipment

project_types.waterline: Pressurized water distribution pipe (DIP, PVC, HDPE). Typically 3-6 ft depth. Includes valves, fittings, hydrants.
project_types.sewer: Gravity sewer main (PVC). Deeper depths (6-15 ft), requires grade control. Includes manholes.
project_types.storm_drain: Storm water conveyance (corrugated, RCP). Variable depth. Includes catch basins, manholes.
project_types.gas: Natural gas distribution line. Shallow depth (2-3 ft). HDPE pipe. Requires fusion welding.
project_types.electrical: Underground electrical conduit and duct bank. Variable depth. PVC conduit, concrete encasement.

soil_types.sand: Easy to excavate, needs trench support in wet conditions. Good drainage. Low production impact.
soil_types.clay: Moderate difficulty. Holds shape well but heavy. Can swell when wet. Moderate production impact.
soil_types.gravel: Easy to excavate but doesn't hold trench walls. Needs good bedding material. Low-moderate impact.
soil_types.rock: Requires hydraulic hammer or blasting. Major production impact (60-70% slower). Significant cost adder.

construction_terms.takeoff: The process of measuring quantities from construction plans/blueprints
construction_terms.bid: A formal price proposal submitted to win a construction project
construction_terms.change_order: A modification to the original contract scope, typically adjusting cost and/or schedule
construction_terms.RFI: Request for Information - formal question to the engineer/architect about plans
construction_terms.submittals: Product data, shop drawings, or samples sent to engineer for approval before installation
construction_terms.mobilization: Moving equipment, materials, and crew to the job site at project start
construction_terms.demobilization: Removing equipment and cleaning up at project completion
construction_terms.backfill: Filling the trench back in after pipe is installed and inspected
construction_terms.bedding: Select material placed in the trench bottom for pipe to rest on
construction_terms.compaction: Mechanically compacting soil/fill to required density (typically 95% Proctor)
construction_terms.dewatering: Pumping groundwater out of the trench to allow work in dry conditions
construction_terms.shoring: Trench support system to prevent cave-in (required by OSHA over 5 ft depth)
construction_terms.bore: Drilling horizontally under a road or obstruction to install pipe without open-cutting
construction_terms.open_cut: Cutting through pavement/surface to install pipe in a trench
construction_terms.thrust_block: Concrete block poured behind pipe fittings to resist pressure forces
construction_terms.potholing: Carefully exposing existing utilities before digging to avoid hitting them
construction_terms.as_builts: Updated drawings showing what was actually installed vs what was planned
construction_terms.punch_list: List of items to fix or complete before final project acceptance
construction_terms.retainage: Percentage of payment withheld until project completion (typically 5-10%)
construction_terms.bonding: Surety bond guaranteeing contractor will complete the work (bid bond, performance bond, payment bond)
construction_terms.prevailing_wage: Government-mandated minimum wage rates for public works projects (Davis-Bacon)
construction_terms.production_rate: How much work a crew can complete per day (e.g., 150 LF/day of 8-inch waterline)
